Comment: This is a good game to start a discussion on the caro kann from black's point of view. The reason this is true is because black follows a simple positional game by placing all of his pieces on the standard squares.

This move was introduced by Kornchoi and breathed new life into a stale game for black. The idea of this move is to gain tempo by attacking the bishop and manoeuvring the knight to d5

Now that the bishop has been move off the g8-a2 diagonal it is safe to kick the knight out of g5.
My plan after kicking out the knight is to develop the rest of my pieces. After that I will turn my sights on to forcing through a c6-c5 thrust.

This is better than Ne4 because black equalizes with 9. ..Qxd4. with the d pawn gone black has a solid game.
For black it is almost always safe to play this move and prevent white from playing Bf4
In the caro-kann the knight on e5 a very frequent theme for white.

Black avoids early piece exchanges in favor of completing his development. By the way the black queen almost always goes to c7. The reason for this is that it prepares for the critical c6-c5 thrust. 

I don't want to get to deep into caro kann strategies but the c6-c5 thrust is critical to blacks chances of winning.

The h4-h5 is also another classical attacking theme for white. In this situation black is quite safe as it would take white some time in order to mount attack against the black king. However, the same can not be said for white as black is already in king hunting mode.

The real weakness in white's position is the d-file so I put my rook on it.
